David,

Is there any chance you could try talking with the ant folks about
=
"level 1" support for junit4 in there? I was actually going to do it,
but i=
t'd probably be better for somebody with more knowledge of what
is involved=
 to take on the task.

-- Ben

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, David Saff <sa=
ff@...> wrote:
>
> Marcy,
> 
> There's three possible levels of support:
> =

> 1) JUnit 4 tests run natively, just like JUnit 3 tests.  This will 
> ha=
ppen in Eclipse 3.2 M6, to be released March 31.  It was intended for 
> th=
e Feb. 17 release, but there were legal surprises.  Sigh.
> 
> 2) JUnit 4 t=
ests run, with full display, using the compatibility
layer.  
> This works =
in all versions of Eclipse since 3.1.  Just add to a JUnit 4 
> test class =
or suite:
> 
> public static Test suite() {
>     return new JUnit4Adapter(=
ThisClass.class);
> }
> 
> To enable this.  This is how the JUnit developer=
s have been running our 
> tests most of the time, and it works very well.
=
> 
> 3) JUnit 4 tests run, with partial display, using the compatibility 
>=
 layer.  This, to the best of my knowledge, is the state of the art in 
> o=
ther IDE's.  The tests run, and failures are indicated, but test
counts 
> =
and names may be missing.
> 
> I'm trying to start conversations with some =
of the other IDE developers 
> about support, but since my fork was already=
 in the Eclipse pie, the 
> most has happened there, to my knowledge.
> 
> =
    David Saff
> 
> Marcy Spector wrote:
> > Which IDEs are supported with =
the latest JUnit 4.0, and is there any 
> > supporting documentation?
> >  =
